Comment: Another Remohgramps game, this one is quick and brutal. Not much to see here (just annotating it because I annotate all my games). We were both playing fast, the game ended in just a few hours while we were both playing frequenly in multiple other games as well - a sure recipe for disaster. White's d4 meets black's Indian System.

And then it gets weird.
And then it gets weird.
Claiming a slice of the center with a secondary threat.
Claiming a slice of the center with a secondary threat.
Getting right into it. White needs to be careful here.

Oops. 5. gxh3? was a blunder and it cost white a piece. Better was 5. Nxe4.
Oops. 5. gxh3? was a blunder and it cost white a piece. Better was 5. Nxe4.
Defending the knight and the pawn.
Defending the knight and the pawn.
7. ... Nh4 is a bit strange, but 6. ... e6 left the knight only this one move to escape white's pawn on h4.
7. ... Nh4 is a bit strange, but 6. ... e6 left the knight only this one move to escape white's pawn on h4.
Doubled pawns. Well, at least white has some doubled pawns too...
Doubled pawns. Well, at least white has some doubled pawns too...
... But not any more.
... But not any more.

Getting a little scary. If 10. ... Qxf2, then 11. dxe6 opens the d-file for white to get a back-rank checkmate with 12. Qd8#. Black could prevent it, but now that the threat is on the board, I prefer simply to advance with 10. ... e5 and not have to worry about it.

Holding everything together.
Holding everything together.
Well, so much for castling. But things are going well, so a central king isn't too much of a burden at the moment.

Oops again. 14. ... Qb4?? was truly a decisive blunder. Already down a piece and a pawn, white cannot afford the outright loss of his queen and resigns on the spot. A bit anticlimactic after my near-death experience against the same opponent in our last game (refer to the Giving Him a Little Rope #2 annotation).
